text: (upbeat music)
- Hi everyone, my name's Richard Halkett,
and I'm the director of digital innovation
at Amazon Web Services.
I'm joined here today by David Cohen.

Who's the chief product
and technology officer
of Greenway Health.
First of all, welcome David.
David, maybe you can introduce yourself,

and tell us a little bit
about Greenway Health.

- Yeah, thanks Richard,
it's great to see you again.
So as you said, my name's David Cohen,

I'm the chief product
and technology officer
at Greenway Health.
Greenway is a healthcare technology
solutions and services provider
for the US ambulatory market.

We're part of the Vista
Equity Partners portfolio.

And for us, you know having
that private equity element
has been really helpful for us in terms of

accelerating a lot of
our product ambitions.

I joined Greenway in 2019
and spent a year kind of

reframing our product,
vision and strategy.
And then last year had the opportunity

to consolidate our product
and technology organization
under one umbrella.
And I think having that consolidation

has really helped us to
accelerate our our product roadmap
and then also has a catalyst for us

to pursue the partnership
that we have with AWS.
- Well, thank you, David.
So that's a great introduction.

So I'm looking back now
over about the past sort of
18 months or so.

And we've been working together
with Greenway, with AWS,

with you specifically,
on a host of projects.

Maybe you can tell us a little
bit about how we got started

and how they've proceeded
and where we are now.

- Yeah, that's right, so
our partnership with AWS

and with the Digital
Innovation Team, in particular,
started about 18 months ago.
And Greenway you know,
we play in a highly regulated environment

and quite honestly, Greenway,
like a lot of companies,
we struggled to keep up with those
ever changing rules and regulations.

And we were investing a
very significant portion
of our product roadmap on regulatory.

And quite honestly, we
weren't seeing the rewards
for those investments.
And you know the old Einstein quote,

that definition of insanity
is doing the same thing

over and over again and
expecting different results.

We knew that in order for
us to break out of that

and really look to
leapfrog in the industry,

that we would have to
do something different.

So we engaged with the
Digital Innovation Team,

and that first project
was really focused on
building a data and analytics platform,
which is a significant portion
of the regulatory compliance program.
And once we got some confidence then

in building and working in
a cloud based environment.

we had the ambitions
last year, during COVID,
to launch a a telehealth product.

And Greenway Telehealth was
the first cloud native product
that we built at Greenway.

And for us, it was a
really great proof point
that it's really possible for us

to build cloud native
products in the timeline
that we've all heard about in, you know,
12 to 16 week time horizon.

And now we're started on a
data center exit strategy

as well as other cloud
modernization initiatives.
- Well, it's quite the partnership, David,

and thank you for being
such a great partner,

to you and to your team,
to the whole organization.

It's interesting hearing
you talk about that journey.

It seems that there's been
an interesting interplay
between maybe two cloud related stories,

one around innovation and
another one around migration.

So in your mind, and
again with your kind of,

the dual role that you
perform for the organization,
how do those two relate for you?

- So, yeah, you're asking
a good question, Richard,
about innovation and that's a question
that I get asked a lot.
And I think for Greenway,
we really need our projects to pay off.
We don't necessarily have the luxury of
taking big risks on projects.
And I think it's important for companies
to really understand their risk profile.

And I think about
innovation in three ways.

And one of those is,
I always tell my team,
I'm okay being a fast follower.
So we look at what are other companies

in the industry doing, and
we try to get there quickly.

And then number two, I
think about innovation

in terms of Greenway being
first of industry innovators,

and not necessarily
first of kind innovators.
And so in that regard,

we look at what are other
industries doing well,

and how can we be bring
that to healthcare?

And certainly what we're
seeing across industries,

is this leveraging the
cloud in different capacity
to accelerate businesses.
And then the third thing, for Greenway,
having a cloud partner like AWS,

who is investing
significantly in innovation,

that allows us to leverage
AWS as a partner to innovate,

but not necessarily carry
that same risk profile
within our company.

And then the other thing I'll
say is I really subscribe

to this notion for that for
companies to be successful,

we have to take actions that
will position us for success.

And I would liken that to
the opening of a chess match,
where having a really strong opening
will position you well for the end game.

So at Greenway and through
our partnership with AWS,

we are really looking
at our cloud migration

to be an accelerant for us
from an innovation perspective,
first in terms of having a modern platform
that will deliver on the promises

around organizational
agility and speed to market

and vision to value, but also
looking at the breadth then,

of other capabilities that
we can leverage within AWS
once we have that platform established.
So it's really kind of creating

that potential for innovation
with our cloud strategy.
- That's really interesting, David,

I think that that story
around the interplay
between innovation and migration,

migration creating the
platform for innovation,
innovation driving the business case,

the customer challenges, the
delivery for the migration,
I think is really, really fascinating.

Now, one of the things that
we are really focused on
at Amazon, is we are really focused on
customer centric innovation.

So I wondered if that
had resonated for you.
And if you could share a couple of
customer or business challenges

that you'd identified
and then responded to
on your innovation journey.
- Yeah, sure.
So in healthcare, like in most industries,

if your business is not
leveraging your data assets
to better understand your business,
you're likely gonna lose.
And in healthcare, for our clients,

it's very important for them
to have the right reports,

dashboards, and analytics
tools to make informed

clinical, financial and
operational decisions.

So one of the projects
that we've been working on

in creating a data
analytics platform on AWS,
to give our clients that insight,.
And one of the things that we talked about
is positioning our clients for success,

and the value of creating
a data analytics platform

on AWS means that we have
full access then to SageMaker
and other AI and machine learning tools

that create new opportunities
for us downstream

and really unconstrained
innovation opportunities.

The other thing I'll say
is that if your business
is investing resources in projects
that are not core to your business,
you really just need to stop.
And for healthcare organizations,

they really don't need
to be spending resources
hosting servers in closets.
And Greenway needs to be focused on

developing and delivering
healthcare technology solutions
and services, not data centers.

And that's one of the reasons
why it's so valuable for us

to be focused on migrating
our solutions and services
to the AWS cloud,

so that we can invest our
resources more effectively
for our clients.

- Now, one other thing that
we've seen regularly, David,
and I think you and I have talked about,

is the fact that the technology
is only one piece of this.

It's a vital piece, but
it's only one piece of this.

If you are going to truly
become and transform yourselves
as an innovative smoothing organization
and take full advantage of the cloud,
then there are real organizational

and cultural opportunities
and challenges to address.

So maybe you can tell
me a little bit about

what you've looked at,
what you've learned,
what you've adopted, and also critically,
how you got leadership on board with this.
Because sometimes that can be
one of the greatest challenges.

- Yeah, I'm glad you asked
that question, Richard

because you know, this
has been for Greenway,

as much about culture and
process transformation,

as much as it's been about
a technology project.

And working with the
Digital Innovation Team,
we're very interested in not necessarily
just copying and pasting,
but identifying important process changes
that we could adapt and make our own
and pull into Greenway's process.

And one of those things
that we found to be

particularly effective is this
notion of working backwards,
and in particular the PRFAQ,

or press release and
frequently asked questions
documentation.

So that's something
where you work backwards,
starting with the customer in mind,

and what business problem
you're really trying to address
with the customer,
and then working that backwards to
all the way to project kickoff.
So throughout the entirety of the project,

you maintain line of
sight on what the end goal

and what the success
metrics really look like.
So now we leverage that PRFAQ document

on almost every project
that we do at Greenway.
And just last week, for example,
I found it really interesting that our CFO

was referring back to a
press release document

as a measure of success
for one of our projects.

And that's how I knew we
kind of had gotten there
from a culture, transformation,

and getting the the
C-suite leadership team

ingrained on the new
process and new culture
that we were introducing.

- Well, that's fantastic,
that's a fantastic story

for it to be really beginning
to get that ingrained
in the decision making culture.

Working backwards, it's
a fascinating mechanism,
and we find it really helps to keep

the customer at the center
all the way through.

So I'm just thrilled that it's
had a similar effect for you

in your own particular
culture and environment.
Now, David, on the other side,

I'm sure there have been
challenges along the way.

There's gonna be rough
patches in this journey.

So maybe, are there any
challenges you wanna sort of

let everyone know about
and then how you managed

to get over them, get
around those challenges?
- Yeah, the biggest challenge for us

was really that workforce
transformation piece.
When we first engaged your team, Richard,
we had never really worked in or operated
in a cloud environment before.
So that was something we knew going in

was something that we were
going to really need to be
focused on.
And the approach that we took to that

was creating this, build with,
not build for philosophy,

and by engaging with AWS Pro
Serve, and and other partners,
we really ingrained them

into our team so that our team
was able to come up to speed
relatively quickly on how to develop
in a cloud-based environment.
And the other piece of that is also
the talent acquisition piece.

So Greenway was not
necessarily experienced on

in attracting the right
talent that we need.

And certainly I think, you'll
know you're on the right path
as an organization

when you start to come
to this realization,

that you need roles that you
never even knew existed before.

So we found ourselves out
there hiring data scientists

and cloud business office
analytics or analysts,

as well as cloud platform
services engineers.

So all these different types
of roles that became necessary

for us, as we transitioned
our business into the cloud.
So that was also another shift for us.
But in working with our talent team,
we were quickly able to pivot

and find the right talent
as well as reskilling
our workforce.

- Well, those are certainly
some significant challenges

to overcome, so it'd be great
to see the continued progress
of Greenway on this journey.

Now, David, I think probably
my last question here

really is a lot of organizations
see the potential here.
They also perceive risk.

And one of the big questions
that we always get is,
well, where do I start?
How do you choose the right project?

How do you ensure that
you've got momentum?
How do you ensure you're set for success?
So do you have any advice for people

who are potentially in your
role in other organizations
who are trying to champion this,

they see the benefits,
they do see the risk,

and they're getting
asked a lot of questions.
How do you make sure that you're starting
in the right place, such that you,

to your point about the
opening of the chess game,

you really do set the foundation
for future success here.
- Yeah, that's a great question, Richard,
because when we first started,

I kind of had this vision
of where we wanted to go

as an organization, but
didn't necessarily know
how we were gonna get there.

What I would, when I
first came to Greenway,

one of the first questions I
had for our CTO at the time
is, well, who are we working with
from a cloud partner perspective?
And his answer was,

we're working with all
of them a little bit.
And I guess my framing there
is when you think you're working with
all of the cloud partners,

the reality is you're
not really working well
with any of them.

And I kind of think
about this relationship
like any other relationship,

that you really have to
be fully invested in it
to realize the full value.

And when we really made a
decision to be fully engaged with
and partnered with AWS
I'm just really delighted about the return

that we got from AWS in
terms of the investment

that you guys have made
in this partnership.

And particularly, Richard,
working with you and your team,

and the way you brought
some of the process change
and the working backwards approach,
that really helped us to think about
what is the primary business challenge
that we need to solve with our clients.
And then working that backwards towards

getting a project kicked
off and off the ground.
So that was really great.

And the other piece of
advice that I have is,

thinking back to the Teddy
Roosevelt quote which is,
when faced with any decision,

the best decision that you
can make is the right one,

the second best decision that
you can make is the wrong one,

but the worst decision that
you can make is no decision.
And certainly I've seen a lot of companies
just take way too much time,
evaluating different cloud partnerships,

and also being way too
concerned about vendor lock in.
One of the things that at Greenway,
I think the catalyst for us,

was making that decision that
we were gonna be fully engaged
in working with AWS, and look,

business today requires
companies to be quick,
to have speed, to have agility.

And I think making that
decision has really enabled us

to move forward in the
market fairly quickly.
- Well, those are great insights, David.
I mean, it's interesting listening to you
in our culture here at Amazon,
thinking about our leadership principles,

we do immediately think
of bias for action,

which I think you framed
out really well there,
and also what we call are right, a lot,

really making sure that
you weigh all of the inputs
you need to make the right decision.

I think one thing you've
sort of selflessly

not really covered is I think
that individual leadership

is a really important
thing that we've seen here.

And David, I think that
we've seen great leadership

from you, both within Greenway,
but also in our partnership.
So I wanna thank you very much for that.

And again, it's never an
achievement of an individual,
of course, it's always a team,

but certainly it's important
to have that vision
and that drive right at the center.

So we wanna thank you
for that partnership.

More specifically, David, I
wanna thank you for your time,
all the insights that you've shared,
however often you and I speak,
I learn something new every time,

and hopefully it's
delivered some rich insights
to anybody who's gonna be watching this.

Thanks again, I really appreciate
your time today, David.

- Yeah, thanks Richard,
it's great talking to you.
(upbeat music)
